title: Inflection points from several second derivatives

content.question: <math> <mrow> <msup> <mi>g</mi> <mo>″</mo> </msup> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mi>x</mi> <msup> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> <mo>−</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <mn>2</mn> </msup> <msup> <mrow> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mi>x</mi> <mo>+</mo> <mn>2</mn> </mrow> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mrow> <mn>3</mn> </msup> <mo>+</mo> <mn>1</mn> </mrow> </math> <math> <mrow> <msup> <mi>h</mi> <mo>″</mo> </msup> <mrow><mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi>x</mi><msup> <mrow> <mrow><mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow> <mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow> <mn>2</mn> </msup> <msup> <mrow> <mrow><mo>(</mo> <mrow> <mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow> <mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow> <mn>3</mn> </msup> <mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow> </math> The twice-differentiable functions f, g, and h have second derivatives given above. Which of the functions f, g, and h have a graph with exactly two points of inflection?

topic.text: 5.6: Determining Concavity of Functions over Their Domains

skill.text: Skill 2.E: Describe the relationships among different representations of functions and their derivatives.
